Syllabus

Course Description

SMM635 Data Visualization is a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of data visualization. This module combines theoretical foundations with hands-on experience using industry-standard tools and programming languages. Students will learn to create effective, ethical, and aesthetically pleasing visualizations that communicate complex data insights to diverse audiences.

Learning Outcomes

Upon successful completion of this module, students will be able to:

  1. Analyze the effectiveness of data visualizations using principles of visual perception and design
  2. Design appropriate visualizations for different data types and communication objectives
  3. Implement static and interactive visualizations using Python, R, and web technologies
  4. Evaluate the ethical implications of design choices in data visualization
  5. Create comprehensive data stories that effectively communicate insights

Module Structure

The module runs for 10 weeks with the following components:

  • Lectures (2 hours/week): Theory, principles, and case studies
  • Labs (2 hours/week): Hands-on coding and visualization practice
  • Self-study (6 hours/week): Readings, tutorials, and assignments

Assessment

Component Weight Due Date
Lab Assignments (5 Ã— 4%) 20% Weekly
Midterm Project 30% Week 6
Final Project 40% Week 11
Peer Reviews 10% Ongoing

Lab Assignments

Short weekly assignments that reinforce lecture concepts and develop technical skills.

Midterm Project

Individual project focusing on exploratory data analysis and static visualizations.

Final Project

Group project (2-3 students) creating an interactive dashboard or data story on a topic of your choice.

Peer Reviews

Constructive feedback on classmatesâ€™ visualizations to develop critical evaluation skills.

Module Schedule

Week Topic Lab Focus
1 Introduction to Data Visualization Setup & Basic Plots
2 Visual Perception & Design Principles Grammar of Graphics
3 Color Theory & Typography Color Schemes & Accessibility
4 Statistical Graphics Distributions & Relationships
5 Time Series & Temporal Data Animated Visualizations
6 Spatial Data & Maps Geospatial Visualization
7 Networks & Hierarchies Graph Visualization
8 Interactive Visualizations Plotly & Shiny
9 Dashboards & Data Stories Dashboard Design
10 Ethics & Future of DataViz Project Presentations

Required Software

All software used in this module is free and open-source:

  • Python 3.8+ with Anaconda distribution
  • R 4.0+ with RStudio
  • Visual Studio Code or Jupyter Lab
  • Git and GitHub account
  • Tableau Public (optional)

See the Computing Resources page for installation instructions.

Textbooks and Resources

Required Reading

  • Cairo, A. (2016). The Truthful Art. New Riders.
  • Wilke, C. (2019). Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Oâ€™Reilly. Free online

Recommended Reading

  • Tufte, E. (2001). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information. Graphics Press.
  • Munzner, T. (2014). Visualization Analysis and Design. CRC Press.
  • Kirk, A. (2019). Data Visualisation: A Handbook for Data Driven Design. Sage.

Online Resources

  • Data Visualization Society
  • Observable - Interactive notebooks
  • From Data to Viz - Chart selection guide
  • ColorBrewer - Color scheme selector

Course Policies

Attendance

While lectures are not mandatory, regular attendance is strongly encouraged. Lab sessions include peer activities that cannot be made up.

Late Submission

  • 10% penalty per day for late submissions
  • Assignments more than 5 days late will not be accepted
  • Extensions may be granted for documented emergencies

Academic Integrity

All submitted work must be your own. You may discuss concepts with classmates, but code and visualizations must be created independently. Proper attribution is required for all external resources.

Collaboration Policy

  • Lab assignments: Individual work, discussion encouraged
  • Midterm project: Individual work only
  • Final project: Group work with individual contributions clearly identified

Communication

  • Course website: Primary source for all materials
  • Office hours: Tuesday 4-5 PM or by appointment
  • Email: simone.santoni@institution.edu
  • Response time: Within 48 hours on weekdays

Diversity and Inclusion

This module values diversity and seeks to create an inclusive learning environment. If you have any concerns or suggestions for improving the classroom climate, please donâ€™t hesitate to speak with me.

Accommodations

Students with documented disabilities who may need accommodations should make an appointment with me as soon as possible. All discussions will remain confidential.

Changes to Syllabus

This syllabus may be revised during the term. Any changes will be announced in class and posted on the course website.
